title: Reflect and Discuss
content: A story in the news says that astronomers have made an initial observation of an asteroid that has a significant probability of hitting Earth. A few months later a follow-up story says that astronomers have made additional observations and now state that the asteroid is no longer a threat.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Upon reading the news a friend of yours says, “What’s wrong with these astronomers? First they think we’re going to get hit and then they say we aren’t. Why can’t they get it straight the first time?” What would you tell your friend to help them understand?

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Do you think astronomers should alert the public upon their first observation of an asteroid that has a probability of hitting Earth or wait until they are more certain that an impact will actually occur? Explain your reasoning.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: Do you think astronomers should continue to monitor this asteroid? Explain your reasoning.

question.title: Question #1
question.label: When an asteroid impacts Earth, not all of its kinetic energy is converted to seismic energy or air blast pressure. What other form(s) of energy might result from the conversion of the asteroid’s  kinetic energy? (Hint: Think of other types of explosions.)
